alert.note: Alert for Meriwether; Pike (Georgia) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 28 at 5:08AM EDT until March 29 at 3:17PM EDT by NWS Atlanta
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia... Flint River near Griffin affecting Fayette and Spalding Counties. Flint River near Thomaston affecting Talbot and Upson Counties. Flint River at US 19 near Carsonville affecting Crawford, Upson, Talbot and Taylor Counties. Flint River below Big Branch near Molena affecting Pike and Meriwether Counties. For the Flint River Basin...including Lovejoy, Peachtree City, Fayetteville, Americus, Peachtree City, Woolsey, Sharpsburg, Peachtree City, Peachtree City, Senioa, Griffin, Griffin, Orchard Hill, Molena, Thomaston, Carsonville, Montezuma, Byromville... Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Flint River below Big Branch near Molena. * WHEN...Until tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 28 feet, Flood stage is reached. Minor flooding of the natural flood plain near the gage location begins. Flooding continues to expand into the agricultural and wooded areas downstream from the gage near the Georgia Highway 74 bridge. Elevated homes in this location will see a foot or two of water underneath them. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:00 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 28.3 feet and rising slowly. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 29.7 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage late tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 28 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Additional information is available at weather.gov/atlanta.
